Award.AwardTitle: Preserving the STEM Education Community's Access to the SALG Website and Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SALG instrument [Student Assessment of their Learning Gains] is a web-based software system that allows faculty instructors to register their courses and require or request their students to log into the system to answer questions about the course, specifically the learning components of the course such as course technology, textbook, lectures, labs, discussions, and group projects. It can be used for formative assessment about the design of the course as well as an end of the semester course evaluation. It can be used repeatedly during a semester for both formative and summative assessment of the course. The SALG site was designed and put into operation through an earlier NSF award. The site provides a very easy to use service to its users. It summarizes student survey responses and emails the results back to instructor.

The current project is a salvage operation, designed to move the current platform from one programming language to a more current language (PERL to JAVA). Except for this change, the maintenance of the SALG web site continues to be at the expense of the PI and his team. There is an installed base of 10,000 instructor users who depend on this tool and new users are added every semester.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report for RAPID Grant NSF105/DUE-17625331

The primary purpose of this RAPID grant was to keep the Student Assessment of their Learning Gains (SALG) website online and available to its many users throughout the grant period, and if possible, into the near-term future. (The SALG website is over ten years old and was written in a now-obsolete programming language. The software has become corrupt and cannot be fixed; it must be replaced to be compatible with contemporary hardware and software.) Secondary goals included modifying a new version of the site which is not yet online in order to have a functional site ready in case the existing site failed. Tertiary goals were to add database fields requested by NSF officers overseeing the REU program and possibly testing group functions and working on data aggregation, data analytics and report functions. The SALG Development Group (SDG) is pleased to say that we accomplished the primary and secondary goals and made some progress on some of the tertiary goals.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Making large-scale, high-impact, sustainable improvements to undergraduate STEM education depends on wide-spread, durable adoption of Research-Based Instructional Strategies (RBISs). Such adoption and continued use of RBISs depends on faculty being able to get valid, reliable data about what students learned in their courses and how specific RBISs effected that learning (Henderson and Dancy 2011). For nearly two decades, the Student Assessment of their Learning Gains (SALG) has been the only widely-available instrument that provides teachers with such data, and it has thereby contributed meaningfully to national improvements in undergraduate STEM education over that time period. Originally developed for the undergraduate STEM education reform community, the SALG instrument and website have been updated over time to serve an ever-increasing number of instructors: Over 20,000 instructors have registered on the SALG site and about 16,000 have used SALG in contexts that include universities, liberal arts colleges, community colleges, professional schools, high schools, libraries and museums. Over 12,000 faculty use SALG regularly, and of the 5,000 instructors who use SALG for multiple classes every year, about 3,200 are in STEM disciplines, 1,000 in the social sciences, and 800 in the arts and humanities. Over 500,000 students have completed SALG surveys. SALG data has improved classroom instruction and curricula, enhanced understanding of student learning, and supported the publication of over 600 scholarly articles in English alone.

 

Broader Impacts:

Losing such a valuable resource would negatively affect thousands of faculty across the United States and around the globe. REUs and other NSF-sponsored projects would have been particularly damaged by taking the site offline in the middle of data collection.

 

This RAPID grant allowed us to keep the SALG website up and running with only brief and minor interruptions in service, thus accomplishing our primary purpose. First, this award gave the SDG resources to make emergency repairs as needed to the existing website. Without those resources, we would have had to take the site offline (probably permanently) due to the age and vulnerability of the software, increasing data corruption and incompatibilities with contemporary server operating systems. Second, those same resources allowed us to keep the system online—again with one brief and minor interruption of service—when a security hole in the software was discovered by one of our users. Our programmers were able to find and patch the hole, something we would have been completely unable to do without the resources provided by this grant.

 

We were also able to do significant work on the new Java-based replacement SALG site that the SDG has been working on for the past five years. We significantly modified the user interface to make it more consistent, simpler and easier to use. We have not been able to test it yet, but we believe that users will adapt to and use the new site should the existing site fail. We also tested and refined our database converter so we are 90% sure that we can convert all user data and import it to the new site should the old one fail. (We are only 90% sure because the database corruption continues to grow, adding new layers of complexity that the converter has to filter out. We cannot fully anticipate the impacts of future corruption—we can only be sure about the converter’s ability to convert the data adequately when we test it.) These two accomplishments fulfilled our secondary goal.

 

Due to the unexpected discovery of the security hole, and the resources required to fix it, we were not able to add the database fields requested by NSF/REU officers. That will be added to the next project. We have begun working on data aggregation and report functions, but that work is still in the planning and design stage. Thus, we have made partial progress toward our tertiary goals.
